next, say “ a grave-maker.” The houses he makes
lasts till doomsday. Go, get thee in, and fetch me a
stoup of liquor.

stage.stage: and the Gravedigger digs and sings.

lg.l: In youth when I did love, did love,
Methought it was very sweet
To contract— O— the time for— a— my behove,
O, methought there— a— was nothing— a— meet.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Has this fellow no feeling of his business? He
sings in grave-making.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p:
Custom hath made it in him a property of
easiness.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
’Tis e’en so. The hand of little employment
hath the daintier sense.

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.l: But age with his stealing steps
Hath clawed me in his clutch,
And hath shipped me into the land,
As if I had never been such.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
That skull had a tongue in it and could sing
once. How the knave jowls it to the ground as if
’twere Cain’s jawbone, that did the first murder!
This might be the pate of a politician which this ass
now o’erreaches, one that would circumvent God,
might it not?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: It might, my lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Or of a courtier, which could say “ Good
morrow, sweet lord! How dost thou, sweet lord?”
This might be my Lord Such-a-one that praised my
Lord Such-a-one’s horse when he went to beg it,
might it not?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: Ay, my lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Why, e’en so. And now my Lady Worm’s,
chapless and knocked about the mazard with a
sexton’s spade. Here’s fine revolution, an we had
the trick to see ’t. Did these bones cost no more the
breeding but to play at loggets with them? Mine
ache to think on ’t.

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.l: A pickax and a spade, a spade,
For and a shrouding sheet,
O, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
There’s another. Why may not that be the
skull of a lawyer? Where be his quiddities now, his
quillities, his cases, his tenures, and his tricks? Why
does he suffer this mad knave now to knock him
about the sconce with a dirty shovel and will not tell
him of his action of battery? Hum, this fellow might
be in ’s time a great buyer of land, with his statutes,
his recognizances, his fines, his double vouchers,
his recoveries. Is this the fine of his fines and the
recovery of his recoveries, to have his fine pate full
of fine dirt? Will his vouchers vouch him no more
of his purchases, and double ones too, than the
length and breadth of a pair of indentures? The very
conveyances of his lands will scarcely lie in this box,
and must th’ inheritor himself have no more, ha?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: Not a jot more, my lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Is not parchment made of sheepskins?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: Ay, my lord, and of calves’ skins too.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
They are sheep and calves which seek out
assurance in that. I will speak to this fellow.—
Whose grave’s this, sirrah?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p: Mine, sir.
sp.l: O, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: I think it be thine indeed, for thou liest in ’t.

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
You lie out on ’t, sir, and therefore ’tis
not yours. For my part, I do not lie in ’t, yet it is
mine.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Thou dost lie in ’t, to be in ’t and say it is thine.
’Tis for the dead, not for the quick; therefore thou
liest.

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
’Tis a quick lie, sir; ’twill away again
from me to you.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: What man dost thou dig it for?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p: For no man, sir.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: What woman then?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p: For none, neither.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Who is to be buried in ’t?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
One that was a woman, sir, but, rest
her soul, she’s dead.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
How absolute the knave is! We must speak by
the card, or equivocation will undo us. By the
Lord, Horatio, this three years I have took note of
it: the age is grown so picked that the toe of the
peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier, he
galls his kibe.— How long hast thou been
grave-maker?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
Of all the days i’ th’ year, I came to ’t
that day that our last King Hamlet overcame
Fortinbras.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: How long is that since?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
Cannot you tell that? Every fool can
tell that. It was that very day that young Hamlet
was born— he that is mad, and sent into England.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Ay, marry, why was he sent into England?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
Why, because he was mad. He shall
recover his wits there. Or if he do not, ’tis no great
matter there.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
’Twill not be seen in him there. There
the men are as mad as he.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: How came he mad?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p: Very strangely, they say.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: How “ strangely”?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p: Faith, e’en with losing his wits.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Upon what ground?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
Why, here in Denmark. I have been
sexton here, man and boy, thirty years.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: How long will a man lie i’ th’ earth ere he rot?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
Faith, if he be not rotten before he die
( as we have many pocky corses nowadays that will
scarce hold the laying in), he will last you some
eight year or nine year. A tanner will last you nine
year.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Why he more than another?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
Why, sir, his hide is so tanned with his
trade that he will keep out water a great while; and
your water is a sore decayer of your whoreson dead
body. Here’s a skull now hath lien you i’ th’ earth
three-and-twenty years.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Whose was it?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
A whoreson mad fellow’s it was.
Whose do you think it was?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Nay, I know not.

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p:
A pestilence on him for a mad rogue!
He poured a flagon of Rhenish on my head once.
This same skull, sir, was, sir, Yorick’s skull, the
King’s jester.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: This?

sp.speaker: GRAVEDIGGER
sp.p: E’en that.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Let me see. Alas, poor
Yorick! I knew him, Horatio— a fellow of infinite
jest, of most excellent fancy. He hath bore me on his
back a thousand times, and now how abhorred in
my imagination it is! My gorge rises at it. Here hung
those lips that I have kissed I know not how oft.
Where be your gibes now? your gambols? your
songs? your flashes of merriment that were wont to
set the table on a roar? Not one now to mock your
own grinning? Quite chapfallen? Now get you to my
lady’s chamber, and tell her, let her paint an inch
thick, to this favor she must come. Make her laugh
at that.— Prithee, Horatio, tell me one thing.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: What’s that, my lord?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Dost thou think Alexander looked o’ this
fashion i’ th’ earth?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: E’en so.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: And smelt so? Pah!

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: E’en so, my lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
To what base uses we may return, Horatio!
Why may not imagination trace the noble dust of
Alexander till he find it stopping a bunghole?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p:
’Twere to consider too curiously to consider
so.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
No, faith, not a jot; but to follow him thither,
with modesty enough and likelihood to lead it, as
thus: Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander
returneth to dust; the dust is earth; of earth
we make loam; and why of that loam whereto he
was converted might they not stop a beer barrel?
sp.l: Imperious Caesar, dead and turned to clay,
Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.
O, that that earth which kept the world in awe
Should patch a wall t’ expel the winter’s flaw!
sp.stage: Enter King, Queen, Laertes, Lords attendant, and the corpse of Ophelia, with a Doctor of Divinity.
sp.l: But soft, but soft awhile! Here comes the King,
The Queen, the courtiers. Who is this they follow?
And with such maimèd rites? This doth betoken
The corse they follow did with desp’rate hand
Fordo its own life. ’Twas of some estate.
Couch we awhile and mark.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: What ceremony else?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: That is Laertes, a very noble youth. Mark.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: What ceremony else?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.l: Her obsequies have been as far enlarged
As we have warranty. Her death was doubtful,
And, but that great command o’ersways the order,
She should in ground unsanctified been lodged
Till the last trumpet. For charitable prayers
Shards, flints, and pebbles should be thrown on her.
Yet here she is allowed her virgin crants,
Her maiden strewments, and the bringing home
Of bell and burial.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: Must there no more be done?

sp.speaker: DOCTOR
sp.l: No more be done.
We should profane the service of the dead
To sing a requiem and such rest to her
As to peace-parted souls.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: Lay her i’ th’ earth,
And from her fair and unpolluted flesh
May violets spring! I tell thee, churlish priest,
A minist’ring angel shall my sister be
When thou liest howling.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: What, the fair Ophelia?

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: Sweets to the sweet, farewell!
I hoped thou shouldst have been my Hamlet’s wife;
I thought thy bride-bed to have decked, sweet maid,
And not have strewed thy grave.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: O, treble woe
Fall ten times treble on that cursèd head
Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense
Deprived thee of!— Hold off the earth awhile,
Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
Now pile your dust upon the quick and dead,
Till of this flat a mountain you have made
T’ o’ertop old Pelion or the skyish head
Of blue Olympus.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: What is he whose grief
Bears such an emphasis, whose phrase of sorrow
Conjures the wand’ring stars and makes them stand
Like wonder-wounded hearers? This is I,
Hamlet the Dane.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: The devil take thy soul!

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Thou pray’st not well.
I prithee take thy fingers from my throat,
For though I am not splenitive and rash,
Yet have I in me something dangerous,
Which let thy wisdom fear. Hold off thy hand.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Pluck them asunder.

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: Hamlet! Hamlet!

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Good my lord, be quiet.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Why, I will fight with him upon this theme
Until my eyelids will no longer wag!

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: O my son, what theme?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: I loved Ophelia. Forty thousand brothers
Could not with all their quantity of love
Make up my sum. What wilt thou do for her?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: O, he is mad, Laertes!

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: For love of God, forbear him.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: ’Swounds, show me what thou ’t do.
Woo’t weep, woo’t fight, woo’t fast, woo’t tear thyself,
Woo’t drink up eisel, eat a crocodile?
I’ll do ’t. Dost thou come here to whine?
To outface me with leaping in her grave?
Be buried quick with her, and so will I.
And if thou prate of mountains, let them throw
Millions of acres on us, till our ground,
Singeing his pate against the burning zone,
Make Ossa like a wart. Nay, an thou ’lt mouth,
I’ll rant as well as thou.

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: This is mere madness;
And thus awhile the fit will work on him.
Anon, as patient as the female dove
When that her golden couplets are disclosed,
His silence will sit drooping.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Hear you, sir,
What is the reason that you use me thus?
I loved you ever. But it is no matter.
Let Hercules himself do what he may,
The cat will mew, and dog will have his day.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I pray thee, good Horatio, wait upon him.
To Laertes. Strengthen your patience in our last night’s speech.
We’ll put the matter to the present push.—
Good Gertrude, set some watch over your son.—
This grave shall have a living monument.
An hour of quiet thereby shall we see.
Till then in patience our proceeding be.

div.head: Scene 2

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: So much for this, sir. Now shall you see the other.
You do remember all the circumstance?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Remember it, my lord!

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting
That would not let me sleep. Methought I lay
Worse than the mutines in the bilboes. Rashly—
And praised be rashness for it: let us know,
Our indiscretion sometime serves us well
When our deep plots do pall; and that should learn us
There’s a divinity that shapes our ends,
Rough-hew them how we will—

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: That is most certain.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Up from my cabin,
My sea-gown scarfed about me, in the dark
Groped I to find out them; had my desire,
Fingered their packet, and in fine withdrew
To mine own room again, making so bold
( My fears forgetting manners) to unfold
Their grand commission; where I found, Horatio,
A royal knavery— an exact command,
Larded with many several sorts of reasons
Importing Denmark’s health and England’s too,
With— ho!— such bugs and goblins in my life,
That on the supervise, no leisure bated,
No, not to stay the grinding of the ax,
My head should be struck off.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Is ’t possible?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Here’s the commission. Read it at more leisure.
But wilt thou hear now how I did proceed?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Being thus benetted round with villainies,
Or I could make a prologue to my brains,
They had begun the play. I sat me down,
Devised a new commission, wrote it fair—
I once did hold it, as our statists do,
A baseness to write fair, and labored much
How to forget that learning; but, sir, now
It did me yeoman’s service. Wilt thou know
Th’ effect of what I wrote?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Ay, good my lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: An earnest conjuration from the King,
As England was his faithful tributary,
As love between them like the palm might flourish,
As peace should still her wheaten garland wear
And stand a comma ’tween their amities,
And many suchlike ases of great charge,
That, on the view and knowing of these contents,
Without debatement further, more or less,
He should those bearers put to sudden death,
Not shriving time allowed.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: How was this sealed?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Why, even in that was heaven ordinant.
I had my father’s signet in my purse,
Which was the model of that Danish seal;
Folded the writ up in the form of th’ other,
Subscribed it, gave ’t th’ impression, placed it safely,
The changeling never known. Now, the next day
Was our sea-fight; and what to this was sequent
Thou knowest already.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: So Guildenstern and Rosencrantz go to ’t.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Why, man, they did make love to this employment.
They are not near my conscience. Their defeat
Does by their own insinuation grow.
’Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
Between the pass and fell incensèd points
Of mighty opposites.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Why, what a king is this!

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Does it not, think thee, stand me now upon—
He that hath killed my king and whored my mother,
Popped in between th’ election and my hopes,
Thrown out his angle for my proper life,
And with such cozenage— is ’t not perfect conscience
To quit him with this arm? And is ’t not to be damned
To let this canker of our nature come
In further evil?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: It must be shortly known to him from England
What is the issue of the business there.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: It will be short. The interim’s mine,
And a man’s life’s no more than to say “ one.”
But I am very sorry, good Horatio,
That to Laertes I forgot myself,
For by the image of my cause I see
The portraiture of his. I’ll court his favors.
But, sure, the bravery of his grief did put me
Into a tow’ring passion.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Peace, who comes here?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
Your Lordship is right welcome back to
Denmark.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: I humbly thank you, sir.
Dost know this waterfly?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: No, my good lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Thy state is the more gracious,
for ’tis a vice to know him. He hath much
land, and fertile. Let a beast be lord of beasts and his
crib shall stand at the king’s mess. ’Tis a chough,
but, as I say, spacious in the possession of dirt.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
Sweet lord, if your Lordship were at leisure, I
should impart a thing to you from his Majesty.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
I will receive it, sir, with all diligence of
spirit. Put your bonnet to his right use: ’tis for the
head.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: I thank your Lordship; it is very hot.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
No, believe me, ’tis very cold; the wind is
northerly.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: It is indifferent cold, my lord, indeed.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
But yet methinks it is very sultry and hot for
my complexion.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
Exceedingly, my lord; it is very sultry, as
’twere— I cannot tell how. My lord, his Majesty
bade me signify to you that he has laid a great wager
on your head. Sir, this is the matter—

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: I beseech you, remember.

div.stage: He motions to Osric to put on his hat.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
Nay, good my lord, for my ease, in good faith.
Sir, here is newly come to court Laertes— believe
me, an absolute gentleman, full of most excellent
differences, of very soft society and great showing.
Indeed, to speak feelingly of him, he is the card or
calendar of gentry, for you shall find in him the
continent of what part a gentleman would see.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Sir, his definement suffers no perdition in
you, though I know to divide him inventorially
would dozy th’ arithmetic of memory, and yet but
yaw neither, in respect of his quick sail. But, in the
verity of extolment, I take him to be a soul of great
article, and his infusion of such dearth and rareness
as, to make true diction of him, his semblable is his
mirror, and who else would trace him, his umbrage,
nothing more.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: Your Lordship speaks most infallibly of him.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
The concernancy, sir? Why do we wrap the
gentleman in our more rawer breath?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p:
Is ’t not possible to understand in another
tongue? You will to ’t, sir, really.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
What imports the nomination of
this gentleman?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: Of Laertes?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p:
His purse is empty already; all ’s golden words
are spent.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Of him, sir.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: I know you are not ignorant—

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
I would you did, sir. Yet, in faith, if you did, it
would not much approve me. Well, sir?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes
is—

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
I dare not confess that, lest I should compare
with him in excellence. But to know a man well
were to know himself.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
I mean, sir, for his weapon. But in the imputation
laid on him by them, in his meed he’s
unfellowed.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: What’s his weapon?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: Rapier and dagger.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: That’s two of his weapons. But, well—

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
The King, sir, hath wagered with him six Barbary
horses, against the which he has impawned, as I
take it, six French rapiers and poniards, with their
assigns, as girdle, hangers, and so. Three of the
carriages, in faith, are very dear to fancy, very
responsive to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and
of very liberal conceit.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: What call you the “ carriages”?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p:
I knew you must be edified by the margent
ere you had done.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: The carriages, sir, are the hangers.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
The phrase would be more germane to the
matter if we could carry a cannon by our sides. I
would it might be “ hangers” till then. But on. Six
Barbary horses against six French swords, their
assigns, and three liberal-conceited carriages—
that’s the French bet against the Danish. Why is this
all “ impawned,” as you call it?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
The King, sir, hath laid, sir, that in a dozen
passes between yourself and him, he shall not
exceed you three hits. He hath laid on twelve for
nine, and it would come to immediate trial if your
Lordship would vouchsafe the answer.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: How if I answer no?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p:
I mean, my lord, the opposition of your person
in trial.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Sir, I will walk here in the hall. If it please his
Majesty, it is the breathing time of day with me. Let
the foils be brought, the gentleman willing, and the
King hold his purpose, I will win for him, an I can.
If not, I will gain nothing but my shame and the odd
hits.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: Shall I deliver you e’en so?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
To this effect, sir, after what flourish your
nature will.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: I commend my duty to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Yours. Osric exits. He does well to commend
it himself. There are no tongues else for ’s
turn.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p:
This lapwing runs away with the shell on his
head.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
He did comply, sir, with his dug before he
sucked it. Thus has he ( and many more of the same
breed that I know the drossy age dotes on) only got
the tune of the time, and, out of an habit of
encounter, a kind of yeasty collection, which carries
them through and through the most fanned
and winnowed opinions; and do but blow them to
their trial, the bubbles are out.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.p:
My lord, his Majesty commended him to you by
young Osric, who brings back to him that you
attend him in the hall. He sends to know if your
pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will
take longer time.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
I am constant to my purposes. They follow
the King’s pleasure. If his fitness speaks, mine is
ready now or whensoever, provided I be so able as
now.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.p: The King and Queen and all are coming down.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: In happy time.

sp.speaker: LORD
sp.p:
The Queen desires you to use some gentle
entertainment to Laertes before you fall to play.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: She well instructs me.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: You will lose, my lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
I do not think so. Since he went into France, I
have been in continual practice. I shall win at the
odds; but thou wouldst not think how ill all’s here
about my heart. But it is no matter.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p: Nay, good my lord—

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
It is but foolery, but it is such a kind of
gaingiving as would perhaps trouble a woman.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.p:
If your mind dislike anything, obey it. I will
forestall their repair hither and say you are not fit.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p:
Not a whit. We defy augury. There is a
special providence in the fall of a sparrow. If it be
now, ’tis not to come; if it be not to come, it will be
now; if it be not now, yet it will come. The
readiness is all. Since no man of aught he leaves
knows, what is ’t to leave betimes? Let be.

div.stage: A table prepared. Enter Trumpets, Drums, and Officers with cushions, King, Queen, Osric, and all the state, foils, daggers, flagons of wine, and Laertes.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Come, Hamlet, come and take this hand from me.

div.stage: He puts Laertes’ hand into Hamlet’s.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Give me your pardon, sir. I have done you wrong;
But pardon ’t as you are a gentleman. This presence knows,
And you must needs have heard, how I am punished
With a sore distraction. What I have done
That might your nature, honor, and exception
Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madness.
Was ’t Hamlet wronged Laertes? Never Hamlet.
If Hamlet from himself be ta’en away,
And when he’s not himself does wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet does it not; Hamlet denies it.
Who does it, then? His madness. If ’t be so,
Hamlet is of the faction that is wronged;
His madness is poor Hamlet’s enemy.
Sir, in this audience
Let my disclaiming from a purposed evil
Free me so far in your most generous thoughts
That I have shot my arrow o’er the house
And hurt my brother.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: I am satisfied in nature,
Whose motive in this case should stir me most
To my revenge; but in my terms of honor
I stand aloof and will no reconcilement
Till by some elder masters of known honor
I have a voice and precedent of peace
To keep my name ungored. But till that time
I do receive your offered love like love
And will not wrong it.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: I embrace it freely
And will this brothers’ wager frankly play.—
Give us the foils. Come on.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: Come, one for me.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: I’ll be your foil, Laertes; in mine ignorance
Your skill shall, like a star i’ th’ darkest night,
Stick fiery off indeed.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: You mock me, sir.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: No, by this hand.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Give them the foils, young Osric. Cousin Hamlet,
You know the wager?

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Very well, my lord.
Your Grace has laid the odds o’ th’ weaker side.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I do not fear it; I have seen you both.
But, since he is better, we have therefore odds.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: This is too heavy. Let me see another.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: This likes me well. These foils have all a length?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.l: Ay, my good lord.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.—
If Hamlet give the first or second hit
Or quit in answer of the third exchange,
Let all the battlements their ordnance fire.
The King shall drink to Hamlet’s better breath,
And in the cup an union shall he throw,
Richer than that which four successive kings
In Denmark’s crown have worn. Give me the cups,
And let the kettle to the trumpet speak,
The trumpet to the cannoneer without,
The cannons to the heavens, the heaven to earth,
“ Now the King drinks to Hamlet.” Come, begin.
And you, the judges, bear a wary eye.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Come on, sir.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.p: Come, my lord.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: One.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.p: Judgment!

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.p: A hit, a very palpable hit.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.p: Well, again.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Stay, give me drink.— Hamlet, this pearl is thine.
Here’s to thy health.
sp.stage: He drinks and then drops the pearl in the cup.
sp.l: Give him the cup.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: I’ll play this bout first. Set it by awhile.
Come. They play. Another hit. What say you?

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: A touch, a touch. I do confess ’t.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Our son shall win.

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: He’s fat and scant of breath.—
Here, Hamlet, take my napkin; rub thy brows.
The Queen carouses to thy fortune, Hamlet.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Good madam.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Gertrude, do not drink.

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: I will, my lord; I pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: It is the poisoned cup. It is too late.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: I dare not drink yet, madam— by and by.

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: Come, let me wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: My lord, I’ll hit him now.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: I do not think ’t.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: And yet it is almost against my conscience.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Come, for the third, Laertes. You do but dally.
I pray you pass with your best violence.
I am afeard you make a wanton of me.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: Say you so? Come on.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.l: Nothing neither way.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: Have at you now!

div.stage: Laertes wounds Hamlet. Then in scuffling they change rapiers, and Hamlet wounds Laertes.

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: Part them. They are incensed.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Nay, come again.

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.l: Look to the Queen there, ho!

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: They bleed on both sides.— How is it, my lord?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.l: How is ’t, Laertes?

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: Why as a woodcock to mine own springe, Osric.
I am justly killed with mine own treachery.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: How does the Queen?

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: She swoons to see them bleed.

sp.speaker: QUEEN
sp.l: No, no, the drink, the drink! O, my dear Hamlet!
The drink, the drink! I am poisoned.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: O villainy! Ho! Let the door be locked.
Treachery! Seek it out.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: It is here, Hamlet. Hamlet, thou art slain.
No med’cine in the world can do thee good.
In thee there is not half an hour’s life.
The treacherous instrument is in thy hand,
Unbated and envenomed. The foul practice
Hath turned itself on me. Lo, here I lie,
Never to rise again. Thy mother’s poisoned.
I can no more. The King, the King’s to blame.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: The point envenomed too! Then, venom, to thy work.

sp.speaker: ALL
sp.l: Treason, treason!

sp.speaker: KING
sp.l: O, yet defend me, friends! I am but hurt.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Here, thou incestuous, murd’rous, damnèd Dane,
Drink off this potion. Is thy union here?
sp.stage: Forcing him to drink the poison.
sp.l: Follow my mother.

sp.speaker: LAERTES
sp.l: He is justly served.
It is a poison tempered by himself.
Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet.
Mine and my father’s death come not upon thee,
Nor thine on me.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: Heaven make thee free of it. I follow thee.—
I am dead, Horatio.— Wretched queen, adieu.—
You that look pale and tremble at this chance,
That are but mutes or audience to this act,
Had I but time ( as this fell sergeant, Death,
Is strict in his arrest), O, I could tell you—
But let it be.— Horatio, I am dead.
Thou livest; report me and my cause aright
To the unsatisfied.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Never believe it.
I am more an antique Roman than a Dane.
Here’s yet some liquor left.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: As thou ’rt a man,
Give me the cup. Let go! By heaven, I’ll ha ’t.
O God, Horatio, what a wounded name,
Things standing thus unknown, shall I leave behind me!
If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart,
Absent thee from felicity awhile
And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain
To tell my story.

stage.stage: A march afar off and shot within.

sp.l: What warlike noise is this?

sp.speaker: OSRIC
sp.l: Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland,
To th’ ambassadors of England gives
This warlike volley.

sp.speaker: HAMLET
sp.l: O, I die, Horatio!
The potent poison quite o’ercrows my spirit.
I cannot live to hear the news from England.
But I do prophesy th’ election lights
On Fortinbras; he has my dying voice.
So tell him, with th’ occurrents, more and less,
Which have solicited— the rest is silence.
O, O, O, O!

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Now cracks a noble heart. Good night, sweet prince,
And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest.
Why does the drum come hither?

div.stage: Enter Fortinbras with the English Ambassadors with Drum, Colors, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: FORTINBRAS
sp.l: Where is this sight?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: What is it you would see?
If aught of woe or wonder, cease your search.

sp.speaker: FORTINBRAS
sp.l: This quarry cries on havoc. O proud Death,
What feast is toward in thine eternal cell
That thou so many princes at a shot
So bloodily hast struck?

sp.speaker: AMBASSADOR
sp.l: The sight is dismal,
And our affairs from England come too late.
The ears are senseless that should give us hearing
To tell him his commandment is fulfilled,
That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
Where should we have our thanks?

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Not from his mouth,
Had it th’ ability of life to thank you.
He never gave commandment for their death.
But since, so jump upon this bloody question,
You from the Polack wars, and you from England,
Are here arrived, give order that these bodies
High on a stage be placed to the view,
And let me speak to th’ yet unknowing world
How these things came about. So shall you hear
Of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,
Of accidental judgments, casual slaughters,
Of deaths put on by cunning and forced cause,
And, in this upshot, purposes mistook
Fall’n on th’ inventors’ heads. All this can I
Truly deliver.

sp.speaker: FORTINBRAS
sp.l: Let us haste to hear it
And call the noblest to the audience.
For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.
I have some rights of memory in this kingdom,
Which now to claim my vantage doth invite me.

sp.speaker: HORATIO
sp.l: Of that I shall have also cause to speak,
And from his mouth whose voice will draw on more.
But let this same be presently performed
Even while men’s minds are wild, lest more mischance
On plots and errors happen.

sp.speaker: FORTINBRAS
sp.l: Let four captains
Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage,
For he was likely, had he been put on,
To have proved most royal; and for his passage,
The soldier’s music and the rite of war
Speak loudly for him.
Take up the bodies. Such a sight as this
Becomes the field but here shows much amiss.
Go, bid the soldiers shoot.

div.stage: They exit, marching, after the which, a peal of ordnance are shot off.
